questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with palpitations. His ECG tracing shown below reveals AV dissociation Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?A 50-year-old man presents with palpitations. His ECG tracing, shown below, reveals AV dissociation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Complete (3rd degree) heart block and ventricular tachycardia are most likely to cause AV dissociation on an ECG.
  • Complete heart block is characterised by severe bradycardia due to the absence of AV conduction.
  • ECG demonstrates complete AV dissociation, with independent atrial and ventricular rates.

Explanation of Other Options:

1st degree AV block (Option A): PR interval is uniformly prolonged, but every atrial impulse conducts to the ventricle, so there is no AV dissociation.

Atrial flutter (Option B): Shows regular"sawtooth" atrial activity with variable AV conduction, but P waves (flutter waves) and QRS complexes remain related, not dissociated.

Mobitz type II block (Option C): Some P waves fail to conduct, but conducted beats maintain a constant PR interval; atria and ventricles remain intermittently linked, without full dissociation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented to the emergency room with complaints of palpitations. On admission, the ECG shows an abnormality in QT interval. Which of the following conditions might be associated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • QT interval refers to the time from the start of the Q wave to the end of the T wave
  • It represents the time taken for ventricular depolarisation and repolarisation, effectively the period of ventricular systole from ventricular isovolumetric contraction to isovolumetric relaxation
  • The QT interval is inversely proportional to heart rate.
  • Corrected QT interval (QTc) estimates the QT interval at the standard heart rate of 60 bpm. QTC = QT/√RR (Bazett formula)

Causes of QTc prolongation:

  • Hypokalaemia
  • Hypomagnesaemia
  • Hypocalcaemia
  • Hypothermia
  • Myocardial ischemia
  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Congenital long QT syndrome
  • Drugs (antiarrhythmics Class 1a and III, Macrolides, fluoroquinolones, haloperidol, TCAs, Fluconazole, Terfenadine, Cisapride, etc.)

Causes of Short QT Syndrome (SQTS):

  • Gain-of-function mutations in potassium channel genes:
    • KCNH2 (SQTS1)
    • KCNQ1 (SQTS2)
    • KCNJ2 (SQTS3)
  • Loss-of-function mutations in calcium channel genes:
    • CACNA1C
    • CACNB2
    • CACNA2D1

choices.text: Discordant QRS complexes in the chest leads

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has palpitations. He has a broad complex tachycardia on the ECG. In a broad complex tachycardia. Which of the following would be the strongest indication towards a diagnosis of VT?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Though SVT is classically associated with a narrow QRS, if it occurs in a patient with bundle branch block or aberrant pathway, then a broad QRS complex is seen.
  • Any evidence of AV dissociation, such as a cannon a wave, effectively rules out an SVT.

Features suggestive of VT, rather than SVT with bundle branch block, are:

  • Evidence of AV dissociation (cannon a waves on JVP)
  • fusion and/or capture beats
  • left axis deviation (between 90 and 180 degrees)
  • QRS duration > 140 msec
  • concordance of V leads (monophasic QRS)
  • history of ischaemic heart disease

Explanation of Other Options:

Discordant QRS complexes in the chest leads (Option A): VT is suggested by concordant QRS across precordial leads rather than discordant patterns, making this feature less specific.

Extreme right axis deviation (Option B): VT may show various axes, but extreme right deviation is neither as specific nor as sensitive as evidence of AV dissociation.

Hemodynamic instability (Option C): While common in VT, instability is a clinical consequence, not an ECG diagnostic feature, and can occur with other tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady was found to have Atrial Fibrillation on her ECG. She has a history of hypertension. There was no history of Diabetes, CAD or CVA. The heart rate was 85 min and BP was 140/85 mmHg. What management should be considered next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's heart rate is not fast.
  • She scores 2 on the CHA2DS2-VASc (she is above age 65 and she has hypertension)
  • There is a significant benefit in formal anticoagulation with warfarin to reduce the risk of embolic CVA.

Management of atrial fibrillation (CHA2DS2-VASc score-based):

  • 0-1 (Low risk): Cardioversion within 48 hrs may be done without anticoagulation.
  • >/=2 or High-risk: Anticoagulation before and after cardioversion (duration of cardioversion must be considered).
    • Prefer NOACs (apixaban, dabigatran, rivaroxaban, edoxaban) over warfarin.
    • Use warfarin (INR 2-3) in patients with mechanical valves or moderate/severe mitral stenosis.
  • Unknown/ AF>48hrs: Anticoagulation for >/=3 weeks before and 4 weeks after cardioversion, or rule out thrombus via TEE/CT.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient complains of dizzy spells. Upon admission, he has an ECG which shows a PR interval of 0.6s and a QT interval of 0.50s. Which one of the following medications could be responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Terfenadine is a first-generation antihistamine that blocks cardiac hERG potassium channels, delaying ventricular repolarisation and producing a marked QT prolongation, as seen with a QT interval of 0.50 seconds.

  • QTc is prolonged if > 0.44 s in men or > 0.46 s in women
  • QTc > 0.50 s is associated with an increased risk of torsades de pointes
  • QTc is abnormally short if < 0.35 s.

Drugs causing QT prolongation: (ABCDEFGH)

  • anti-Arrhythmics (Ia and III)
  • antiBiotics (macrolides, fluoroquinolones)
  • anti-psyChotics (haloperidol), Chloroquine
  • antiDepressants (TCAs), Diuretics (thiazides)
  • antiEmetics (ondansetron)
  • antiFungals (Fluconazole)
  • Grapefruit juice
  • antihistamine (Terfenadine)

Explanation of Other Options:

Aspirin (Option A): Does not affect cardiac conduction intervals or ventricular repolarisation.

Amoxicillin (Option B): A β-lactam antibiotic with no impact on PR or QT intervals.

Digoxin (Option D): Typically shortens the QT interval and slows AV nodal conduction, prolonging PR but not QT.

questions.text: A 27-year-old fit and healthy male has an ECG as part of his medical examination for employment as a pilot. There is no significant personal medical or family history. The ECG tracing of the patient is shown below. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In an asymptomatic individual with an incidental Wolff-Parkinson-White pattern and no high-risk features, current guidelines advise conservative management with reassurance rather than medication or invasive therapy.

  • WPW is a relatively common cardiologic abnormality occurring in approximately 0.1 to 3% of the population.
  • It is due to an accessory pathway, and although most subjects are asymptomatic, there is a small risk of sudden death from tachyarrhythmias (<0.6%).
  • Asymptomatic patients are treated only in the presence of high-risk features (WPW detected in the first two decades, history of AF, h/o arrhythmic symptoms, associated congenital heart disease, familial WPW)
  • Radiofrequency ablation (Option C) is the treatment of choice in those identified to be at risk.
  • Anti-arrhythmic agents like procainamide and flecainide (Option B) are useful for terminating AVRT in WPW syndrome and in those with atrial fibrillation.
  • AV nodal blocking agents (beta blockers (Option A), verapamil, adenosine) are contraindicated in patients with WPW syndrome with tachyarrhythmias.

questions.text: The earliest ECG abnormality in a patient with hyperkalemia is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ECG changes start to manifest usually when serum K > 6 mEq/L.
  • The earliest ECG finding in a patient with hyperkalemia is tall, tented T waves
  • It is followed by other changes like P wave flattening, PR prolongation, QRS widening, appearance of a sine wave pattern.
  • Hypokalemia is characterised by ECG changes like T wave flattening/inversion, ST segment depression, appearance of 'u' wave and prolonged QU interval.

Explanation of Other Options:

QRS widening (Option A): Occurs later as severe hyperkalemia slows intraventricular conduction.

PR prolongation (Option C): Reflects AV nodal delay seen after initial T-wave changes in more advanced hyperkalemia.

U waves (Option D): Are a feature of hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Left axis deviation is seen on the ECG in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In inferior myocardial infarction, loss of electrical forces from the necrosed inferior wall causes the net ventricular depolarisation vector to shift upward and leftward

Causes of Left Axis Deviation:

  • Left anterior fascicular block
  • Left bundle branch block
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Inferior MI
  • Ventricular ectopy
  • Paced rhythm
  • Wolff-Parkinson White syndrome

Causes of Right axis deviation:

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Right bundle branch block
  • Left posterior fascicular block
  • Dextrocardia
  • Chronic lung diseases with cor pulmonale
  • Ventricular ectopic rhythms
  • Preexcitation syndrome (Wolff-Parkinson-White type B)
  • Lateral wall myocardial infarction
  • Secundum atrial septal defect

Explanation of Other Options:

Ebstein's anomaly (Option B): In Ebstein's anomaly, massive right-atrial enlargement and an 'atrialized' right ventricle create low-voltage QRS complexes without a consistent leftward axis shift; it does not produce classic LAD.

Large ventricular septal defect (Option C): A significant VSD volume-loads the left ventricle, often pulling the axis slightly leftward but not into the LAD range; it does not cause the vector shift seen in fascicular block or inferior MI.

Patent ductus arteriosus (Option D): Chronic left-to-right shunting leads to left ventricular volume overload and a normal or mildly left-shifted axis, but not true LAD.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with new-onset palpitations. She also commented that she had lost weight recently despite an increased appetite. Examination reveals a goitre and a degree of exophthalmos. During physical examination, she fell unconscious. Blood pressure was 66/40 mmHg. ECG tracing is shown below. What is the appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is haemodynamically compromised due to a rapid ventricular rate associated with AF.
  • The emergency management is DC cardioversion 200J, followed by 360J if sinus rhythm is not attained.
  • The underlying diagnosis in the above patient is Graves' disease, as evidenced by the clinical features of thyrotoxicosis with goitre and exophthalmos.
  • Though anti-thyroid drugs like carbimazole or radioactive iodine therapy form the mainstay of long-term therapy, they are not suitable for the management of AF with hemodynamic instability.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anticoagulation (Option A): Important for stroke prevention, but not the immediate priority in an unstable patient.

Carbimazole (Option B): Essential for long-term management of Graves' disease, but too slow to address acute hemodynamic collapse.

Intravenous amiodarone (Option D): Contraindicated in thyroid storm due to high iodine content and delayed onset; not appropriate in acute instability.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with severe central crushing chest pain. ECG shows evidence of an inferior myocardial infarction. He receives fibrinolysis, Heparin and Aspirin. Four hours after the initial presentation, he starts feeling dizzy and breathless. His pulse is 40 bpm regular, BP 80/50. Heart sounds are soft, and the chest is clear to auscultation. ECG shows 2:1 AV block with T wave inversion inferiorly. IV atropine was administered but had no effect. What is the next most important treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has had an inferior MI, which is commonly associated with conduction abnormalities. He now develops heart block, which leaves him bradycardic, symptomatic and with a low BP. Transvenous temporary pacing immediately restores adequate ventricular rate and perfusion.
  • Isoprenaline (Option B) is contraindicated in acute MI due to its positive inotropic effects and arrhythmogenic potential.
  • IV Dopamine (Option A) may increase heart rate via β1 stimulation, but does not guarantee reliable AV conduction in high-grade block.
  • A temporary pacemaker would deal with the situation until the inferior MI has fully resolved.
  • There is no indication for a permanent pacemaker (Option D) at present. Permanent implantation is deferred until stabilisation and assessment of block persistence; initial management requires temporary pacing.

questions.text: All of the following electrocardiograph waveforms are matched correctly to the cardiac cycle that they represent, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The electrocardiogram waveforms are labelled alphabetically, beginning with the P wave, which represents atrial depolarisation.
  • PR interval shows the AV nodal delay to allow for the filling of the ventricles.
  • The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarisation (Option B), and the ST-T-U complex (ST segment, T wave, and U wave) represents ventricular repolarisation. (Option C)
  • The J point is the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment.
  • Atrial Repolarisation (STa and Ta) is usually too low in amplitude to be detected, but it may become apparent in conditions such as acute pericarditis and atrial infarction.
  • U wave follows the T wave and represents late ventricular repolarisation, most likely of Purkinje fibres and mid-myocardial (M) cells. (Option D)

choices.text: Mobitz type I second-degree heart block
Mobitz type II, second-degree heart block

questions.text:
A marathon athlete comes for a routine evaluation. You note an irregular pulse; an electrocardiogram (rhythm strip) is shown below. Which of the following is a correct diagnosis?

Which of the following is a correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ECG shows a progressively lengthening PR interval followed by a nonconducted P wave ("dropped beat"), then a shortened PR after the pause.
  • This is Mobitz type I second-degree heart block, or Wenckebach heart block.
  • The periodic failure of conduction in Mobitz type I block is characterised by a progressively lengthening PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, and a pause that is less than two times the immediately preceding RR interval on the electrocardiogram (ECG).
  • The ECG complex after the pause exhibits a shorter PR interval than that immediately preceding the pause.
  • This ECG pattern most often arises because of decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. This rhythm is usually benign and may be seen in very fit athletes due to high vagal tone.

Explanation of Other Options:

First-degree heart block (Option A): Features a uniformly prolonged PR interval without any dropped beats.

Mobitz type II block (Option C): PR intervals remain constant before an unexpected dropped QRS, without progressive prolongation.

Type III heart block (Option D): Complete AV dissociation with independent P and QRS rates, not seen here.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with the new onset of palpitations and shortness of breath. The accompanying electrocardiogram is obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ECG shows regular "sawtooth" flutter waves best seen in leads II, III, and aVF at a rate of approximately 300/min, with a fixed ventricular response due to 2:1 atrioventricular conduction. There are two flutter waves for every QRS complex, consistent with typical atrial flutter with 2:1 conduction.
  • This rhythm arises from a large re-entrant circuit in the right atrium around the tricuspid valve (cavotricuspid isthmus-dependent), generating uniform atrial depolarisations known as flutter waves.
  • Recognition of atrial flutter is critical because it often requires different acute management (e.g., rate control with AV nodal blockers, consideration of synchronised cardioversion) and definitive therapy (e.g., catheter ablation) compared to other supraventricular tachycardias.

Explanation of Other Options:

AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia (Option A) presents as a sudden-onset, regular narrow-complex tachycardia without sawtooth flutter waves.

AV re-entrant tachycardia (Option B) involves an accessory pathway and typically shows retrograde P waves or delta waves in sinus rhythm, not the classic flutter pattern.

Atrial fibrillation (Option D) is characterised by an irregularly irregular rhythm without discrete, uniform P or flutter waves.

questions.text: The drug of choice in a patient with torsades de pointes is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Torsades de pointes is characterised by twisting pattern of ventricular tachycardia in ECG that occurs in the background of prolonged QT interval
  • The drugs, metabolic abnormalities etc. that can prolong QTc can potentially lead to torsades de pointes.
  • IV Magnesium sulphategiven at a bolus dose of 1-2 gm is considered to be effective in this condition and is considered the treatment of choice. Magnesium stabilises cardiac myocyte membranes and suppresses early afterdepolarizations. It shortens the QT interval and terminates torsades by reducing calcium influx.
  • Metoprolol and lignocaine (Options B & D) may also be effective in some cases but are not the first-line agents.
  • Amiodarone (Option A) is avoided in such patients as it can further prolong the QTc interval.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with recurrent syncopal attacks was admitted for further evaluation. There is family history of sudden cardiac death. His ECG tracing is given below which revealed a peculiar finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia(ARVD) is characterised by replacement of cardiac myocytes by fibrofatty tissue
  • It can predispose the affected patients to ventricular arrhythmias, heart failure and sudden cardiac death.
  • The classical ECG finding is the 'epsilon wave' that appears as a blip or wiggle buried at the end of the QRS complex. It is best visualised in the ST segment of leads V1 and V2.
  • Naxos syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition associated with ARVD, palmoplantar keratoderma and woolly hair.

Explanation of Other Options:

Brugada syndrome (Option A): Shows coved or saddleback ST-segment elevation in V1-V2, not epsilon waves.

Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (Option B): Demonstrates a short PR interval and delta wave, without late QRS deflections.

Hypothermia (Option D): Produces Osborn (J) waves - positive deflections at the J point - distinct from the low-amplitude epsilon wave.

questions.text: Which of the following denotes a normal cardiac axis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cardiac axis represents the overall direction of electrical activity as it spreads through the cardiac conduction system
  • The normal cardiac axis is directed downward and slightly to the left. It falls within the range of -30° to +90°.
  • Deviations outside this range indicate conduction abnormalities or chamber enlargement that alter the net depolarisation vector.
  • Left Axis Deviation (LAD): When the QRS axis is less than -30°. (Option C)
  • Right Axis Deviation (RAD): When the QRS axis is greater than +90°. (Option B)
  • Extreme Axis Deviation: Occurs when the QRS axis lies between -90° and +180° ("Northwest Axis") (Option A)

Causes of Left Axis Deviation:

  • Left anterior fascicular block
  • Left bundle branch block
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Inferior MI
  • Ventricular ectopy
  • Paced rhythm
  • Wolff-Parkinson White syndrome

Causes of Right axis deviation:

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Right bundle branch block
  • Left posterior fascicular block
  • Dextrocardia
  • Chronic lung diseases with cor pulmonale
  • Ventricular ectopic rhythms
  • Preexcitation syndrome (Wolff-Parkinson-White type B)
  • Lateral wall myocardial infarction
  • Secundum atrial septal defect

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG tracing shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Right bundle branch block - features

  • QRS duration > 120 msec
  • RSR pattern in V1-V3
  • Wide slurred S waves in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5-V6)

Left Bundle branch block - features (Option D)

  • QRS duration > 120 msec
  • Absent Q wave in lateral leads (I, aVL, V5, V6)
  • Tall, monomorphic R wave in lateral leads
  • Deep S wave in V1 and V2

Brugada syndrome (Option A) shows coved or saddleback ST-segment elevations in V1-V3, not an RSR′ pattern with wide S waves.

WPW syndrome (Option B) demonstrates a short PR interval and delta wave leading into a widened QRS, without the RSR′ morphology of bundle-branch block.
